data.title: Warnings for long commit messages does not work anymore
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.11.0 (9122ec4b1068bd391e41974f46a4b54c1b9c90f9, 2017-04-05T21:13:24.700Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 4.8.0-41-generic
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|vscode-eslint|dbaeumer|1.2.8|
|githistory|donjayamanne|0.2.0|
|tslint|eg2|0.11.0|
|prettify-json|mohsen1|0.0.3|
|final-newline|samverschueren|0.3.2|
|join-lines|wmaurer|0.2.2|
|local-history|xyz|1.1.1|;


---
The Git UI used to show a warning when the commit summary exceeded 50 or so characters. This warning is gone and I can't find a config option.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Enter a commit message with more than 50 characters in the first line.

data.title: Add embeded browser
data.body:
I searched this request but couldn't find one. So I opened a new one. 

When developing web apps I switch between the editor and a browser very often. An embedded browser can improve developer performance. I think it can be placed under left bar bellow extension button. After clicking that button bookmarks may appear. Bookmarks may send GET, POST, PUT etc.. 

I believe many extension developers may contribute to the embedded browser if you add such feature.

data.title: Lost feature: fading out files in the SCM tree not under root directory
data.body: Prior to v1.11.1, the SCM pane (using git) had a nice feature where it would fade out changed files which were not under the root directory for the editor window. Since updating, this appears not to work any more. Is this a regression, can it be reenabled through a setting somewhere, or was it purposely removed for some reason?

data.title: Backspace between the beginning of the line and the first non-space character should erase a "tabful" of spaces

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.12.0
- OS Version: Windows 10

This is something Sublime does, and I find it very useful.

Say you have tabs set to 4 spaces - if you press tab, the editor will behave as if you have added a tab, but in reality it will **add** spaces. The opposite should also be true - if you hit backspace, it should **remove** enough spaces to make it look like you have deleted a tab.

Example (• = space, | = tab stop, _ = cursor)

    ••••|••_•let x: string;

When hitting backspace, the editor should simply erase all the four spaces that make up the "tab", both before and after the cursor

    ••••let x: string;

That's only important at the beginning of a line for me (there may be other use cases) and of course a preference setting to control would be perfectly fine. Thanks

data.title: Some private variables are not displayed in the debugger window
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.11.1
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Have a similar code in place (can't put the original one here)
```ts
namespace A1 {
    export abstract class A extends B {
        public abstract el1: Object;
        private _el2: string;
        public get el2(): string { return this._el2; };
        private _el3: number;
        public get el3(): number { return this._el3; };
    }
}
namespace A2 {
   export class APlus extends class A1.A {
        public el1: Object = { foo:bar }
        public baz: X;
   }
}
```
2. Start to debug and instantiate a new object APlus.
3. On the debug window you'll see: **el1, _el2, el2, el3, baz** but you won't see **_el3**.

My debug configuration is the following:
```
   {
            "type": "node",
            "protocol": "inspector",
            "request": "launch",
            "name": "Local",
            "program": "${workspaceRoot}/node_modules/protractor/bin/protractor",
            "args": ["${workspaceRoot}/protractor.conf.js", "--troubleshoot"],
            "cwd": "${workspaceRoot}",
            "sourceMaps": true,
            "runtimeArgs": [
                "--harmony", "--expose_debug_as=v8debug"//, "--trace-warnings"
            ],
            "skipFiles": [
                "<node_internals>/**/*.js",
                "node_modules/selenium-webdriver/**/webdriver.js",
                "node_modules/protractor/**/browser.js"
            ]
        },
```

PS: I need to explicitly state the protocol as **inspector** (even though I use Node 7.8.0) because since 1.11.0 VS Code will launch the tests in **legacy** if I set it as **protocol:auto**

PS2: Don't know if this will help, but in the case where this is implemented if I check the __proto__ element, then I can only see el2 and el3 (and both state TypeError: Cannot convert undefined or null to object)

data.title: Opening a file replaces the last opened file in the editor, instead of being opened alongside it
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.12.0
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open any project, open the explorer
2. click on file A (any file) in the explorer - it will open in an editor
3. click on file B (any file which is not A) - it will replace A in the editor
4. The same happens for search

Expected behaviour: B should open alongside A. if I opened A I want it to stay open until I expressely close it, even if I haven't edited yet

data.title: HTML Format and Jekyll Front Matter

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
I am working on a Jekyll project. There is an HTML in some of the layouts. I have configured to format code on save.

When I save format change this

```
---
layout: default
---
```

to this

```
--- layout: default ---
```

I have played with this parameters

```
"html.format.preserveNewLines": true,
"html.format.endWithNewline": true
```

But nothing seams to change.

And of course Jekyll does not process properly this file until I manually change that Front Matter.

Can we do something about this?

data.title: Default keybinding problem
data.body:
Hi,

Just got the new 1.11 version, and there’s a problem on macOS:

![combinaisons_de_touches_-_lmde bac_2017-04-06_17-22-01](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6781337/24762197/ee476d0c-1aed-11e7-9a74-993ff03b052c.jpg)

This key combination is the actual one for doing a pipe character: |
As it’s a very common symbol in dev, this shorcut really should be changed, or it will lead the large majority of macOS users to change the default key map.

Thanks!

data.title: Fast click global continuation searching
data.body:
This is an idea that I think `ripgrep` now makes possible due to the speed.

Use cases this idea would improve:

1. **Continuous searching finding related symbols:**
    1. Search for symbol
    1. See another interesting symbol on a matching result line
    1. Type that symbol into search and search again
    1. Repeat N number times until finding your target information.

1. **Variation of above:**
    1. Search for symbol
    1. Result filename is of interest
    1. Search again entering the filename
    1. Repeat any combination of the above until target information found

**Proposed improvement for above use cases:**

- While holding a modifier key in the search results, clicking the mouse over a word will automatically initiate another search using that word.  
    - The user can click on the filename and it will search for that excluding the extension.  
    - The user can click any word in the result text and initiate another immediate search
- Also would be useful to be able to do this inside a document

data.title: Can't open multiple instances of VSCode without using File->New Window
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: VS 1.11
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Close all instances of VSCode and open a new one.
2. Try to open a new instance of VSCode from a source other than File->New Window in the currently running instance.
3. Nothing happens.
4. In your first instance, File->New Window for instance 2.

Not sure if this is by design (seems like it may be something to do with opening an associated file from `explorer` and checking for a running instance to open it in).

data.title: Can't open same folder in multiple instances of VSCode
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.11
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a directory (empty or with files) in an instance of VSCode
2. File -> New Window to launch another instance of VSCode
3. File -> Open Folder and select the directory opened in VSCode in the first instance.
4. Nothing happens.
5. Open another directory, different (or nested in the original) in the 2nd instance and it loads fine.

This was a workaround to not being able to drag out tabs into separate forms (as Visual Studio does), not sure if this is by design or not but it didn't seem too logical.

I've since installed the Insider's build to support VS style tabs in case anyone was going to suggest it 😄 :

data.title: [css] support cancelation requests

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
The CSS language server should react to cancelation requests

- don't evaluate completions for cancelled requests
- look into cancelling building a large AST.

data.title: CTRL + Mouse Wheel to zoom in/ou
data.body:
It's a minor issue but I've guess many people (like myself) are already used to have ctrl + mouse wheel to zoom in/out.

Guess it should be easy to implement as well since you already allow to zoom in, using (ctrl +/-/0)

Thanks

data.title: Debug: unable to create launch.json when diff editor is open
data.body:

1. have a change from git open ("Working Tree")
2. click on gear icon to produce a launch.json

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/900690/24761032/912aeeda-1aea-11e7-810f-8cd27eb62757.png)
